title: Giuliani asked State Dept to grant visa to former Ukranian prosecutor whom Biden wanted removed
text:
President Donald Trump's personal attorney Rudy Giuliani allegedly asked the State Department to grant a visa to the former Ukrainian prosecutor whom Joe Biden wanted removed.

Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for European and Eurasian Affairs George Kent made the claim to Congress this week, four people familiar with the closed-doors testimony told CNN.

Kent told Congress that Giuliani wanted a visa so Viktor Shokin could travel to the US and, after the State Department denied the request, Guiliani asked the White House to reverse the decision.

Shokin was pushed out of his post in 2016 by several world leaders, including then-Vice President Biden, who said Shokin was not doing enough to prosecute corruption cases.

But Trump and the GOP have disputed, with unfounded claims, that Biden was trying to help his son, Hunter, who was on the board of a gas company Shokin was investigating.

President Donald Trump's personal attorney Rudy Giuliani (left) allegedly asked the State Department to grant a visa to the former Ukrainian prosecutor Viktor Shokin (right). When the State Department denied the request, Giuliani asked the White House to overturn the decision

The claim was made by Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for European and Eurasian George Kent made a closed-doors testimony to Congress on Friday. Pictured: Kent arrives for a closed session before the House Intelligence committee on October 15, 2019

Shokin was never granted a visa to visit the US, but Giuliani did eventually speak with over Skype, CNN reported.

Giuliani has told the news outlet in the past he hoped to speak to the Ukrainian in person because he allegedly had dirt on Democrats.

During the Skype call, Shokin allegedly said he had evidence of coordination between Democrats and Ukrainians.

Guiliani told CNN that Shokin 'believes the current Ambassador Marie L Yovanovitch denied his visa' and said Yovanovitch was 'close to Mr Biden.'

Yovanovitch, the former ambassador to Ukraine, testified before congressional lawmakers one week ago, which was part of the House impeachment inquiry into President Trump.

She claims Trump placed pressure on the State Department to remove her because he had 'lost confidence in her'.

However, her employers told she had done nothing wrong.

When asked for comment from CNN, the State Department said it cannot discuss details of individual visa cases under federal law.

Giuliani allegedly wanted to interview Shokin in person after he promised dirt on former Vice President Biden and Democrats. Pictured: Biden speaks during the Women's Leadership Forum Conference on October 17, 2019 in Washington DC

Biden called for Shokin to be removed in 2016 for not doing enough to prosecute in corruption cases. But the GOP says Biden was trying to help his son, Hunter, who was on the board of a gas company Shokin was investigating. Pictured: Biden and his son, Hunter, attend an NCAA basketball game between Georgetown University and Duke University, January 2010

Neither Giuliani nor the White House responded to requests for comment.

The impeachment probe was sparked by Trump's phone call on July 25 to Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy.

During the call, Trump asked Zelenskiy to meet with Giuliani and US Attorney General William Barr over claims Biden lobbied for Shokin's dismissal.

This led to a whistleblower complaint from an officer within the CIA, whom Trump and other Republicans have called to be identified.

Earlier this week, Giuliani said he would not comply with a congressional subpoena to turn over documents related to his work.
description: A new report reveals that  President Donald Trump's personal attorney Rudy Giuliani allegedly asked the State Department to grant former Ukranian prosecutor Viktor Shokin a visa to the US.
